title: I don't want a threesome: 11 things people don't get about bisexual women | Metro News
text:
Stephanie Barrett for Metro.co.uk Sunday 12 Feb 2017 5:06 pm Orange Is The New Black’s Alex and Piper, who has relationships with men and women (Picture: Netflix) 
Bisexuality – some people find it confusing. 
It’s relatively easy to define straight people or gay people, but bisexual people seem to have thrown the manuals onto the fire and danced around the ashes. 
If sexuality is a spectrum, bisexuality covers the broad and baffling ‘middle bit.’ It’s a land of questions and confusion. 
Well, I’ve been a proud resident of the ‘middle bit’ for over a decade, and I’m here to shine a light on some of the questions people have asked me. 1. No, I don’t fancy all of my friends 
Or have ‘twice as many options.’ My standards are sky high, baby. 2. It’s not just a phase 
I realised I was attracted to women when I was 11 years old. 
During that period, I also became attracted to gothic clothes, rock music, and black lipstick. 
But, guess what? Sexuality tends to be a bit more permanent than bad fashion choices. 
Bisexuality isn’t usually a phase – science says so. 
And even if it was , that wouldn’t make it less meaningful. 
Much like my unfortunate experiments with black lipstick, it still happened. (Picture: Netflix) 3. And I’m definitely not confused 
Yes, some people do transition from being bi to straight (or gay) but, pro tip – it’s usually safest to assume people know more about their own bedroom preferences than you do. 4. Yes, I’m still bisexual when I’m dating a man (or a woman) 
My relationship status changes – my sexuality doesn’t. 5. Yes, I’m still bisexual even if I’ve only ever dated one gender 
I’ve dated both genders, but not all bisexual people have, and that’s okay. 
Attraction happens in the mind. I mean, you don’t have to have dated Tom Hiddleston to know you fancy him, right? (For the record, Tom, I’m single). 6. I’m not doing this for attention 
We’re British – if I wanted attention, I’d express a dislike of tea. 
Beverage preferences are a matter of public interest, sexuality isn’t. (Picture: Getty) 7. No, not all women are bisexual 
Yes, studies have indicated female sexuality is more fluid , but just because some of us have kissed a girl and liked it, doesn’t make all women bisexual. 
Time to put your threesome fantasies to bed. 8. On that note, no, I don’t want to have a threesome with you and your partner Ok, we’d make an exception for them (Picture: Getty) 
Unless you’re Blake Lively and Ryan Reynolds, in which case, yes, yes I do. 9. I don’t prefer one gender over the other 
While I might be more likely to date men, I wouldn’t say I prefer them. 
That makes it sound as if I’d always rather be with a man, and that couldn’t be further from the truth. I want whoever I’m with. 10. Actually, it might not be about gender at all 
Yes, we tricked you – I apologise on behalf of bisexuals worldwide. 
Despite the fact that ‘bi’ is a prefix that means having two (like a bicycle has two wheels, and a bisected cake has two halves (both are mine), bisexuality doesn’t always mean being attracted to only two genders. Bisexuality is a spectrum, and so is gender (Picture: Getty) 
For one thing, gender isn’t that simple . 
Some people just don’t identity with being male or female. 
So some bisexual people would call themselves ‘genderblind.’ Or ‘pansexual’–‘pan’ meaning ‘all’ and not an illicit attraction to frying pans – to indicate more than one gender exists and we’re totally down with that. 11. Not all bisexuals are the same 
Bisexuality is a broad spectrum, and it means different things to different people. 
There really are no rules, and we like it that way.
